I did a reasonably simple experiment using AC and 2 LED's. It was electronics, but the idea was that when you hit 50Hz, (the standard AC frequency in the uk) Instead of seeing flashing led's they seem to be constantly on. It's sort of comparable to looking at two objects at different distances, and try and see when you can't distinguish them anymore, but temporally not spatially. So you could say that human eyes can see upto 25hz? Although it's sort of a backwards way of looking at it.

The answer would be, none. because our eyes don't work like that.

The complicated answer might go as far as to calculate the minimum amount of photons we can see, but because they don't have mass, I really can't see anything good coming from that conversation

I don't think you can give something like a frame rate. Your brain is not digital. But we do "remember" a "frame" (if you want to call it that) for a short time. That is why we can see movies or a line if we watch a moving laserdot in the dark. Easy enough to measure. Get a laser, move it with fixed speed, get the length of the line you see. But i guess it's about 1/24 second, because movies need to have at least that much frames.

--Part 2-- So instead of producing thrust by moving a whole lot of air behind the tank, the M1 engine's power turbine directly drives a transmission which reduces the high-speed, low torque output of the turbine, to high torque, low speed rotation which drives the tank's wheels.

Check out AgentJayZ's channel, specifically /watch?v=AtqXfzHz_b8 for a whole lot of jet engine info.  Wikipedia says the M1A2 uses an AGT 1500 gas turbine.  All or most modern jet planes use turbofan engines, which actually use the power turbine to spin a larger outer fan which then sends most of its air outside of the turbine, producing the majority of the plane's thrust.  Fundamentally, there's very little difference -- a turbine is a turbine, after all.

You might think so initially, but it would be too hard to do in practice. The scale reading shown in the video is too imprecise, it likely is not equipped to track or output response time histories, and its dynamic characteristics (inertia, stiffness, and damping) are unknown without extensive tests. This would make it too hard to interpret the reported force measurements. Kinematics through motion tracking is much more precise and dependable.

clarifying list,

computer science is a different form of engineering than computer engineering.

comp-sci deals with algorithms and programing

computer engineering deals with advancing the power of a computer and it's hard ware.

there are 8 branches of engineering (not including the myriad of other  professions, ie biomedical engineering, aerospace engineering these are masters)

mechanical
chemical
electrical
industrial
civil
computer science
computer (this and the above are different)
environmental
so if the engineers that you deal with are failing they are probably civs or have skill in a different part of the field.

This doesn't change the amount of force that the grasshopper uses to move itself, only the amount of force that each leg imparts on its jumping surface. We don't need to know anything about an object besides its acceleration (which we know very precisely) and its mass (which we don't) to know force. We're also ignoring force of gravity, which would only be about 2% of the total anyway. The number of legs and the SA of their feet would affect any calculation of deformation of a surface though.

I got 925 m/s^2, which yields 0.0925 N. Close enough!

What method did you go about to calculate power?

Power is the rate of work, ie. Work/Time. Work is Force*Distance. Did you assume the force was the same for a certain distance and then measure the distance using the tracker software? 

Or did you do something else completely? Maybe P = Force*Max Velocity? Using this method I got 5.4 kW/kg. Did I go wrong somewhere? P-W = Power/Mass = (0.925 [N] * 5.846 [m/s]) / (0.0001 [kg]) = 5.4 [kW/kg]

No it would not be. 400m/s/s means that if the grasshopper's legs were rocket engines with a power of 0.04 N, and they were functioning for 1 second in vacuum, then the grasshopper would pick a speed of 400m/s. Grasshopper jumping off leaf: conservation of momentum. Since the leaf has a velocity after the jump unlike a rigid object which will essentially have 0 velocity before and after jump, grasshopper's initial jumping velocity will decrease compared to jumping off a rigid object.

400m/(s^2) means that the grasshopper would be going 400 m/s if it was accelerating (at it's maximum acceleration rate) for 1 whole second. The grasshopper was only accelerating at this rate for a small fraction of a second, meaning the final speed was no where near 400 m/s. For example, if the grasshopper had accelerated at 400 m/(s^2) for .01 seconds, that would create a takeoff (maximum, do do drag thereafter) speed of 4 m/s, since 400m/(s^2)*.01s=4m/s

The grasshopper is accelerating at 400 meters per second per second (no, that duplication isn't a typo). In essence, if the grasshopper were to keep accelerating at that rate, he would get to the speed 400 meters per second in one second's time. If he were to keep accelerating at that rate for a full two seconds, he would reach 800 meters per second. However, he's only accelerating for a fraction of a second, and therefore only reaches a speed of an equivalent fraction.

Gravity affects* all bodies. The reason small creatures can survive is because of terminal velocity & the square-cube law.

As something changes size (2x, 1/2x, etc.) the change in volume is proportional to the change^3, & the change in surface area is proportional to change^2. This means that volume AKA mass changes faster than area does. Air resistance is based on area, & air resistance defines terminal velocity. So small animals have a low terminal velocity. Cats are still too big though.

Imagine a pendulum hanging from the mirror in your car.  If you were to speed the car up (increase velocity), the pendulum would move backwards. If you measure the amount the the pendulum swings backwards you can figure out how much you accelerated.  In this scenario the speedometer would be like a math function, and measuring the pendulum would be the derivative of that function.  It's a way of measuring the change in something.

Perhaps it's a southern thing, I know what I was brought up to say, and I as well bring my four girls up to say it to others. I say sir to strangers, to superiors, to subordinates. In my area if I simply respond with Yes, or No, it is considered by most to be casual at best, and disrespectful at worst. The responses yeah, and naw, are seen as even more disrespectful. My girls call me daddy regularly, and they do not ALWAYS address me as sir. It our way of showing someone we respect them.
